message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest spinal cord compression, which is often caused by metastatic cancer. Among the options, only prostate cancer commonly metastasizes to the spine and can cause this symptom. Elevated prostate-specific antigen levels in the serum can also indicate the presence of prostate cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest spinal cord compression, likely due to metastatic prostate cancer, which can elevate prostate-specific antigen levels. None of the other options are associated with spinal cord compression.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest spinal cord compression, which can be caused by metastasis of prostate cancer. Therefore, the most likely finding is elevated prostate-specific antigen in the serum. Palpable thyroid nodule or elevated carcinoembryonic antigen is not related to the symptoms, and skin examination is not relevant to the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including weakness of lower extremities and urinary incontinence, along with multiple sclerotic lesions in the thoracic and lumbar vertebrae, suggest metastatic prostate cancer. Therefore, the most likely finding in further evaluation would be elevated prostate-specific antigen in the serum. All other options are unrelated to the symptoms and findings in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described in the question are consistent with spinal cord compression. The presence of urinary incontinence suggests a possible prostate-related issue. Elevated prostate-specific antigen in the serum can indicate prostate cancer or benign prostatic hyperplasia, both of which can result in spinal cord compression. None of the other options are likely to be related to the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The worsening back pain and neurological symptoms suggest spinal cord compression or metastatic disease. Among the given options, only elevated prostate-specific antigen in the serum is related to the spinal cord compression as it can indicate prostate cancer that has metastasized to the spine. Palpable thyroid nodule, elevated carcinoembryonic antigen, and irregular, asymmetric mole are not related to the patient’s symptoms.
